awd_titl_txt: Mechanism for Lithium Dendrite Formation in Solid State Electrolytes
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to store energy from intermittent renewable energy sources and the ongoing electrification of light-duty vehicle transportation increase the demand for high energy density batteries that have acceptable durability and cost. The utilization of lithium (Li) metal as the battery anode holds great potential to significantly improve the energy density. However, thus far, use of this anode material has been unsuccessful with the conventional liquid electrolytes because of compromised durability and safety issues arising from Li dendrite growth that shorts the battery. Solid electrolytes have been considered as the ideal solution to prevent dendrite growth because of their high mechanical strength. However, recent reports indicate formation of lithium dendrites in Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) solid electrolytes by mechanisms that remain inconclusive. This fundamental research project aims to elucidate the origin of lithium dendrite formation in LLZO solid electrolytes. The scientific insights will be used to design solid electrolytes that result in rechargeable Li batteries with improved energy and power densities and improved lifetime. The interdisciplinary nature of this research will provide training opportunities for researchers at all levels including postdoctoral researcher, graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of electrochemistry, materials sciences and energy. Additional outreach activities include mentoring undergraduates through the Chem-E Car and GEMSTONE programs at the University of Maryland College Park. 

The overall objective of this fundamental engineering science project is to identify the mechanisms of lithium dendrite formation in LLZO solid electrolytes, and to use these insights to design new solid electrolytes for dendrite-free Li plating at large current densities. The dynamic evolution of depth distribution of Li dendrites in LLZO will be studied using an in-situ neutron depth profile (NDP) technique. A precise three-dimensional lithium distribution in LLZO will be reconstructed using focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM). A computational study using first-principle calculation at the atomic scale and electro-chemo-mechanical modeling at the continuum level will be implemented to understand the distribution of lithium dendrites in LLZO. Combining the advantages of NDP (in situ, non-destructive, lithium selective, statistical), FIB-SEM (high-resolution, chemical analysis), and the computation studies at both atomic-level and continuum level, unprecedented information will be obtained on the mechanism of lithium dendrite formation in LLZO. Novel approaches to improve the dendrite suppression capability of LLZO will also be tested based on the new understandings. The fundamental knowledge gained from this project will promote the development of safe, high-energy all-solid-state Li batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The need to store energy from intermittent renewable sources and the ongoing electrification of transportation increase the demand for safe batteries with high energy densities. The utilization of Li metal as anode holds great potential to significantly improve the energy density of batteries but has been proven unsuccessful with the conventional liquid electrolytes because of compromised cyclability and safety issues arising from Li dendrite growth. Solid electrolytes have been considered as the ideal solution to prevent dendrite growth because of their high mechanical strength. However, recent reports indicate that the formation of lithium dendrites in solid electrolytes is much easier than that in the liquid electrolytes by mechanisms that remain elusive.

Combining multiple advanced characterization and computational techniques including in-situ neutron depth profiling, focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy, first principles calculation, and electro-chemo-mechanical modeling, this project validated the hypothesis that the residual electronic conductivity plays an important role in the dendrite formation in inorganic solid electrolytes. Novel approaches to improve the dendrite suppression capability of inorganic solid electrolytes, particularly by engineering the interphases between solid electrolytes and Li metal were also developed based on the new understandings. The results supported by this project have led to four publications on top tier journals including Nature, Nature Energy, Chem, and ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces. The results were also shared with solid-state battery community through multiple presentations during the Materials Research Society and Electrochemical Society conferences. The fundamental knowledge gained from this project will promote the development of safe, high-energy all-solid-state Li batteries.

In addition to the research outcome, the project also offered training and education opportunities for three postdocs, six graduate students, and two undergraduate students, and one of the postdocs supported by the project is a faculty member at a research university. The accomplishments resulting from the projects were also widely recognized by the community based on multiple society awards for the PI and the postdoc from the Electrochemical Society. Additionally, the project also provided ample opportunity for outreach activities to underrepresented groups through the Maryland Day and the Black Families Technology Awareness Day.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2023
Modified by: Chunsheng Wang
